Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
Not all audiovisual materials have been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact university-archives@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information. Audiovisual RecordingsIn the Year 2000: Cleveland AmoryAV11 sound tape reelscirca 196711CD ACCESS 12:52

Original Format: ¼" Open Reel Audio, Duration: 63 min.Bedford-Stuyvesant Clinics, Part 2AV83WNYU (Radio station : New York, N.Y.)1962 March 13283
Scope and Contents
This recording appears to be part two of the recording "Urban League Presents: Bedford-Stuyvesant Looks to Psychiatric Needs" on AV523. It is unclear whether this recording ever aired on WNYU.
Related Material

Format: 1/4" Open Reel Audio, Duration: 23 min., Preservation note: "The lecture portions have audio in the left channel only, but the music samples have audio in both channels."Pipes and Pedals of New YorkAV115WNYU (Radio station : New York, N.Y.)1 sound tape reels28:381962 August 61/4" audio tape reel3AV115
Related Material
This tape is related to materials in RG 39.5, Records of WNYU (Radio Station: New York, N.Y.).
Scope and Contents
This recording concerns the history of organ instruments. It was created by the Documentary Unit of the Communications Arts Group and broadcasted on WNYU. The host was Walt Michaels and the organist player featured on the recording is Dick Wolitoch.

Richard Nixon Resignation (Tape 1 of 2)
Scope and Contents
This recording includes the complete resignation speech of former U.S. President Richard Nixon, as well as clips from NBC, CBS, and ABC news coverage of the event.
Provenance
This recording was donated by the Office of Media Production.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Original format: 1/2 inch open reel video; Transfer Technician Notes: "This tape contains news segments prior to, during, and after Richard Nixon's resignation, as well as a brief documentary on his rise to the presidency. All segments suffer from moderate to severe generational loss, notably heavy image echo. The documentary section exhibits inherent dirt, dust, and scratches from the original film source. There are frequent dropouts and tape wear during the content, and occasional tape damage. Occasional sync errors occur, with some segments suffering from a pronounced skew error. Severe audio buzz and hiss throughout, and audio distortion are all inherent to the original recording."Nixon, Richard M. (Richard Milhous), 1913-1994Richard Nixon Resignation (Tape 2 of 2)AV18491 videoreels (1/2 inch)8 August 19741551849
Richard Nixon Resignation (Tape 2 of 2)
Scope and Contents
This recording includes footage of Richard Nixon during his presidency, as well as interviews with Bella Abzug, Gabe Pressman, and New York University School of Law Dean Robert McKay. It also includes footage of Gerald Ford being sworn in as Vice President, and the appointment of Henry Kissinger as Secretary of State.
Provenance
This recording was donated by the Office of Media Production.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Original format: 1/2 inch open reel video; Transfer Technician Notes: "This tape contains news segments during the aftermath of Richard Nixon's resignation and the presidential appointment of Gerald Ford. Content includes several documentary segments that exhibit inherent dirt, dust, and scratches from original film source(s). All segments suffer from moderate to severe generational loss, notably heavy image echo. There are frequent dropouts and tape wear during the content, and occasional tape damage. Occasional sync errors occur, with some segments suffering from a pronounced skew error. Occasional jitter occurs. Severe audio buzz and hiss throughout, and audio distortion are all inherent to the original recording."Abzug, Bella S., 1920-1998Ford, Gerald R., 1913-2006Nixon, Richard M. Highlights in Jazz #21: Chet Baker & Frank Foster (Tape 1 of 3)
Scope and content
These recordings may be part of a long-running series of concerts produced by Jack Kleinsinger, titled "Highlights in Jazz." The intermission music is titled "Loud Majority."
Performers on this recording include Frank Foster, Chet Baker, Bob Mover, Hal Galper, Dave Shapiro, Jimmy Madison, and Gene Bertonicini.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Original format: 1/2 inch open reel video; Transfer Technician Notes: "As with other tapes in this collection, there is an inherent constant sync error that is stabilized by time base correction, but ultimately results in moderate to severe flagging throughout. Additionally, there is a frequently severe skew error during the first third of content, which is triggered by inherent exposure adjustments during the performance. Skew and flagging contribute to mild to moderate jitter. Elsewhere, there are occasional mild dropouts and tape wear. Occasional inherent exposure adjustments and mild ghosting. Luma is adjusted to mitigate clipping from glare."Baker, ChetHighlights in Jazz #21: Chet Baker & Frank Foster (Tape 2 of 3) AV20921975-06-16532092

Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Original format: 1/2 inch open reel video; Transfer Technician Notes: "As with other tapes in this collection, there is an inherent constant sync error that is stabilized by time base correction, but ultimately results in moderate to severe flagging throughout. This flagging is generally above the performers, but intensifies in low lighting. Mild image jitter throughout. Elsewhere, there are frequent mild dropouts, and occasional tape damage. Occasional inherent exposure adjustments and mild ghosting. Luma is adjusted to mitigate clipping from glare. Audio distortion is inherent to the original recording."Highlights in Jazz #21: Chet Baker & Frank Foster (Tape 3 of 3) AV20931975-06-16532093

Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Original format: 1/2 inch open reel video; Transfer Technician Notes: "As with other tapes in this collection, there is an inherent constant sync error that is stabilized by time base correction, but ultimately results in moderate to severe flagging throughout. This flagging is generally above the performers, but intensifies in low lighting. Mild image jitter throughout. Elsewhere, there are frequent mild dropouts, and occasional tape damage and sync errors. Occasional inherent exposure adjustments and mild ghosting. Luma is adjusted to mitigate clipping from glare. Audio distortion is inherent to the original recording."Jazz, the American Invention #2: Three Generations of Jazz Piano - Roland Hanna, Eubie Blake, Danny Mixon (Tape 1 of 2) AV2095Kleinsinger, JackMixon, DannieBlake, Eubie, 1887-1983Hanna, Roland1973-10-10532095
Jazz, the American Invention #2: Three Generations of Jazz Piano - Roland Hanna, Eubie Blake, Danny Mixon (Tape 1 of 2)
Access copies
Access copies of Tape 2 are available at the University Archives.
Scope and Contents
Performers on this recording include Eubie Blake, Roland Hanna, and Danny Mixon.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Original format: 1/2 inch open reel video; Transfer Technician Notes: "As with other tapes in this collection, there is an inherent constant sync error that is stabilized by time base correction, but ultimately results in various errors throughout. The first minute and 45 seconds have been captured with a different TBC than the rest of the tape. Jitter and flicker observed during this first portion was more acceptable here than in later portions. Similarly, the mild skew error observed for the majority of the tape was much more severe in this first portion. The combination of these two captures represents the best transfer possible. Elsewhere, there are occasional momentary sync errors, seemingly triggered by variations in exposure inherent to the content. Occasional dropouts and tape damage throughout. Head switch error visible throughout, especially pronounced during first segment."Jazz, the American Invention #2: Three Generations of Jazz Piano - Roland Hanna, Eubie Blake, Danny Mixon (Tape 2 of 2) AV20961973-10-10532096
Jazz, the American Invention #2: Three Generations of Jazz Piano - Roland Hanna, Eubie Blake, Danny Mixon (Tape 2 of 2)
Scope and Contents
Performers on this recording include Eubie Blake, Roland Hanna, and Danny Mixon.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Original format: 1/2 inch open reel video; Transfer Technician Notes: "Content generally plays very well. There are several instances of image errors, notably when there is an abrupt shift in lighting. There is also mild image distortion, similar to bearding or jitter throughout. These artifacts are introduced by the TBC, but was determined to be the best possible capture when compared to errors presented by other TBCs. Otherwise, the content plays without major error."Jazz, the American Invention #1: Gospel and Contemporary Black Music - Max Roach Sextet, J.C. AV20981 videoreels (1/2 inch)undated532098
The Politics of Assassination: Mark Lane, Keynote Speaker
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Original format: 1/2 inch open reel video; Transfer Technician Notes: "Majority of content is a presentation by Mark Lane, with some unrelated and/or establishing segments at the very beginning. These first 15 seconds suffer from severe tracking errors. Main segment doesn't begin until about one minute in. Content plays mostly well throughout, with occasional dropouts and tape wear, and one instance of tape damage. There is a scrolling diagonal band of interference that happens throughout, which appears to be inherent to the recording and caused likely by some sot of electrical interference. Occasional inherent exposure adjustments. Loud audio hiss is present throughout, with occasional inherent pops. Content ends abruptly at tail."First New York City Post Card Art Show AV20991975-05-19532099
First New York City Post Card Art Show
Scope and content
This recording depicts a gallery installation at the Contemporary Arts Gallery at New York University.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Original format: 1/2 inch open reel video; Transfer Technician Notes: "Content exists on only about half of this tape. As with other tapes in this collection, the content suffers from a constant control track error that affects image stability, causing severe flagging and skew errors. These skew errors appear to be exacerbated during portions with bright exposure inherent to the original recording. The tape was tested with multiple TBCs - this capture represents the best transfer possible. Occasional crash records result in tracking and vertical hold errors. Occasional mild dropouts and tape damage. Mild head switch error visible throughout."Postcards.M. Scope and contents
This recording is labeled Tape 3 of 3. The University Archives does not have Tapes 1 or 2.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Original format: 1/2 inch open reel video; Transfer Technician Notes: "This tape contains only about 6 minutes of content. As with other tapes in this collection, there is an inherent, constant sync error that is stabilized by time base correction, but ultimately results in moderate to severe flagging throughout. This flagging is generally above the performers, but intensifies on tighter shots. Mild image jitter throughout. Elsewhere, there are occasional mild dropouts and tape wear, and one instance of tape damage. Occasional mild ghosting. Luma is adjusted to mitigate clipping from glare. Audio distortion is inherent to the original recording."JazzHighlights in Jazz #17: Salute to Swing! Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Original format: 1/2 inch open reel video; Transfer Technician Notes: "Content exists on only on about 7 minutes of tape, featuring the end of a Q+A with George McGovern. Moderate image jitter affects content throughout. This error is less problematic than errors presented by other TBCs for this tape. Occasional dropouts and mild tape wear throughout. Head switch error visible throughout. Inherent loss of audio at end of presentation."Great Speakers Series II #2: Ralph Nader

Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Original format: 1/2 inch open reel video; Transfer Technician Notes AV2900: "Headswitch error in underscan. Severe skew error across top of frame throughout entire frame. Attempted to fix this by trying multiple TBCs and decks, this was the best possible quality. Mild Dropouts throughout."
Transfer Technician Notes AV2901: "Entirety of tape suffers from a constant control track error. Multiple TBCs were tested to obtain the best capture possible. Content suffers from persistent flagging and image jitter throughout, as a result of the inherent control track error. Aside from these anomalies, there is recurring mild tape wear and dropouts throughout, and occasional mild tape damage. Image is less stable when camera moves to feature audience questions."Great Speakers Series II #4: Sam ErvinAV2902Ervin, Sam J. (Sam James), 1896-19852 videoreels (1/2 inch)1974-11752902752903

Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Original format: 1/2 inch open reel video; Transfer Technician Notes AV2902: "Content is primarily a static shot of Senator Ervin speaking at a podium. As with other tapes in this collection, there is an inherent constant sync error that is stabilized by time base correction, but ultimately results in moderate flagging throughout. This flagging is generally above the speaker. Mild image jitter throughout. Elsewhere, there are occasional mild dropouts and tape wear. Occasional inherent exposure adjustments and mild ghosting. Audio distortion is inherent to the original recording. Pronounced audio buzzing present during audience Q+A."
Transfer Technician Notes AV2903: "Content recorded on just several minutes near head of tape. As with other tapes in this collection, there is an inherent constant sync error that is stabilized by time base correction, but ultimately results in moderate to severe flagging throughout. Mild image jitter throughout. Elsewhere, there are frequent mild dropouts, and occasional mild tape damage. Occasional inherent exposure adjustments and mild ghosting. Audio distortion is inherent to the original recording."Jazz, the American Invention #4: The Big Band - Thad Jones-Mel Lewis Orchestra, Dee Dee Bridgewater

Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Original format: 1/2 inch open reel video; Transfer Technician Notes AV2904: "Majority of content features a big band performance directed by Les McCann, with several establishing shots in the beginning. A persistent skew error is present in the bottom half of the frame throughout, with some portions more severe than others. This error was less problematic than errors introduced by other TBCs. Otherwise the content plays well, with one instance of momentary sync error, and one instance of minor tape damage. Occasional ghosting and inherent exposure adjustments throughout. Head switch error visible throughout. Mild audio distortion is inherent to the original recording."
Transfer Technician Notes AV2905: "Content plays well throughout. A persistent skew error affecting the bottom half of the frame is visible throughout, and contributes to moderate bearding. Mild to moderate ghosting and tube burn visible, especially following swift movement. Mild head switch error visible throughout. Content ends abruptly at tail."JazzJazz, the American Invention #5: Rhythm & Contemporary Music - Les McCann QuartetAV2906McCann, Les, 1935-Kleinsinger, Jack2 videoreels (1/2 inch)1973-10-31752906752907

Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Original format: 1/2 inch open reel video; Transfer Technician Notes AV2906: "First few minutes feature a number of establishing shots with occasional inherent edits and crash records. Main portion of content begins around 8 minutes in. Les McCann Ltd performance plays well throughout, with occasional tape damage, flicker, ghosting, and mild tube burn. There are occasional portions that exhibit a very mild skew error, but it doesn't persist throughout the performance. High head switch error visible throughout. Moderate inherent audio distortion throughout, particularly during performance."
Transfer Technician Notes AV2907: "Content exists on about a third of the tape. Performance plays well throughout, though there is significant inherent audio distortion. Occasional dropouts and mild tape wear, with one instance of tape damage. Occasional mild ghosting. High head switch error visible throughout."JazzHighlights in Jazz #14: Odetta, David Amram, Pepper Adams, Jerry Dodgion, Herb Bushler, Al Harewoodcuid656Kleinsinger, JackAmram, DavidOdetta, 1930-20082 videoreels (1/2 inch)1974-05-065329081562909

This recording is related to RG 12.2.5, Records of the Loeb Student Center.
Scope and content
This concert took place at the Eisner & Lubin Auditorium at the Loeb Student Center at New York University.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Original format: 1/2 inch open reel video; Transfer Technician Notes AV2908: "Content plays mostly well throughout. Image jitter persists, especially near beginning and end of tape. Occasional dropouts and mild tape wear throughout, with a couple instances of tape damage. Occasional tracking noise. Head switch error visible throughout. Mild inherent audio distortion. Content is inherently without audio for first minute."
Transfer Technician Notes AV2909: "This tape suffers from severe inherent sync errors that result in persistent image jitter and a high head switch error. Multiple captures were performed using combinations of different capture decks and TBCs, and this file represents the best capture possible. Aside from the aforementioned errors, glare from Odetta's guitar triggers an auto-exposure response from the TBC that severely dims the picture. Again, this error was troubleshooted using multiple TBCs, and could not be corrected. The glare occasionally clips the luma. Occasional tape wear and damage occur throughout. Audio distortion is inherent to original recording."JazzHighlights in Jazz #14: Odetta, David Amram, Pepper Adams, Jerry Dodgion, Herb Bushler, Al Harewood (Tape 3 of 3) AV29101 videoreels (1/2 inch)6 May 19741562910
Highlights in Jazz #14: Odetta, David Amram, Pepper Adams, Jerry Dodgion, Herb Bushler, Al Harewood (Tape 3 of 3)
Scope and content
Tape labeled Tape 3 of 3. This is the only recording that the University Archives has of this event.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Original format: 1/2 inch open reel video; Transfer Technician Notes: "Content plays generally well throughout, however the glare from Odetta's guitar triggers an autoexposure response from the TBC that repeatedly dims the image. Her performance here (as well as on another tape) were captured using multiple TBCs, and this file represents the most satisfactory transfer, despite the luma error. Elsewhere, there are occasional dropouts and tape wear, along with recurring image jitter. Persistent edge wear throughout, as well as visible head switching."JazzHighlights in Jazz: Latin Jamcuid657Kleinsinger, Jack2 videoreels (1/2 inch)7 October 19741562911, 2912

The subject of the lecture was Thomas Paine's Common Sense.Untitled Anatomy lectureAV2023c1 sound tape reels1/4" tape reel2
Scope and Contents
The first 7:30 of recording appear to be part of an anatomy class in which the lecturer discusses several bones and muscle groups and even has a drummer perform in order to demonstrate how parts of the body work. Original tape held this recording and two lectures by Floyd Zulli for his "Have You Read...?" class on Sunrise Semester. Recordings on this reel can be identified by Unique Identifiers beginning with 2023.

Scope and Contents
In the spring of 2000, Woody Allen did a two week tour of colleges and universities around the United States with his film "Small Time Crooks" starting at NYU. This is a video of events surrounding the NYU pre-screening, including students receiving tickets, reacting to the film outside of the theater, and engaging in a Q&A session with Woody Allen. Audio drops out at times when B-Roll audience reaction shots have been inserted to footage of Mr. Allen answering questions. Access copy available on DVD: ACCESS 13:4Marshall McLuhan untitledAV44481 videocassettes1184448
Scope and Contents
The video quality of this disc is grainy and the volume is makes it difficult to hear exactly what people are saying The setting is a lecture hall Where McLuhan, Nevitt, and various other people are seated facing an audience. In his discussion there is a reference to being at a conference at the School of Dentistry but nothing is truly specified. The men, mainly McLuhan, discuss how environment effects and is effected by technology while the actual technology is incidental. They further talk about technological breakthroughs and how humans perceive it. Intellectual decline from over stimulation from technology creating a "goal-less" child who is more interested in role playing rather than true decision making thanks to television and radio. Most of the discussion is based on McLuahn's "Laws of Media" which is a four part tetrad of things that share an "interlocking nature" when humans consume media. The four parts are Enhance, Reverse, Retrieve, Obsolescence. The film cuts out frequently and ends abruptly.

Scope and Contents
No title of event given or visible.
The video quality of this disk is clear and the people speaking within the room are relatively easy to hear and comprehend especially when McLuhan speaks.The tape starts in the middle of a group discussion. The setting is in an office with a large table. The audience participates, asking McLuhan questions and receiving answers from him. The majority of the discussion is based on McLuhan's "Laws of Media" which is a four part tetrad of things that share an "interlocking nature" when humans consume media. The four parts are Enhance, Reverse, Retrieve, Obsolescence. His discussion raises concern on mans responsibility for technologies and its effect on humans. He argues that we need studies about technology in order to shape them properly for consumption. Part of his argument is about adverting in the American home as opposed to foreign advertising which is much less prevalent in private lives. He also discusses the effects of politicians becoming visually and verbally known by the general public. The discussion ends with the conclusion that our current media is an "open game" meaning that nothing is finalized. McLuhan concludes that he does not believe there is a solidified answer to his questions. Instead he views it as a continued exploration. The film ends with questions from the audience where McLuhan fields questions, takes business cards, and hands back his portable mic he was using.Flying Saucer MysteryAV504419501215044An Open Mind - Discussions with Dean John SextonAV5135November 18, 1998 & December 15, 1999Approx. 60 minutes1235135Shared University Archives 11328

Alumni Fun was a CBS game show that aired between 1963 and 1966. Alumni from colleges and universities across the United States competed to win money for scholarships. Each show featured two teams of three participants each; they answered questions in a variety of categories to receive points. Teams would continue in competition until defeated.

Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Original format: 1/2 inch open reel video; Transfer Technician Notes: "Much of the content on this tape is of a projected film. Inherent dirt, dust, and scratches appear on the film, and the projection results in inherent flicker throughout. Other effects are inherent to the film, notably frame speed variations. Aside from these artifacts, the tape plays remarkably well. Occasional tape wear and damage occurs, with mild recurring dropouts. Edge wear or a high head switch error is visible in underscan.
